qas.question: What is a willow's flower comprised of?

answers.text: only a few stamens or two carpels

qas.question: What have some structures evolved to protect?
Individual members of enveloping structures are known by what terms?
What appearance are calyx of sepals typically?
The features of flowers which attract pollinators also attract what other creature?
What do sporophylls form that is attractive to pollinators?
In what flower are stamens and sporophylls not able to be distinguished from each other?

plausible_answers.text: the rest of the flower, especially the bud

qas.question: What do corolla of petals function to protect?

plausible_answers.text: in general, white or brightly colored

qas.question: What color is the more delicate willow?
What characteristics of the flower attract sporophylls?

context: The flower may consist only of these parts, as in willow, where each flower comprises <a0_0>only a few stamens or two carpels<a0_0/>. Usually, other structures are present and serve to protect <a1_0>the sporophylls<a1_0/> and to form <b5_0>an envelope<b5_0/> attractive to pollinators. The individual members of these surrounding structures are known as <a2_0>sepals and petals<a2_0/> (or tepals in flowers such as <b6_0>Magnolia<b6_0/> where sepals and petals are not distinguishable from each other). The outer series (calyx of sepals) is usually <a3_0>green and leaf-like<a3_0/>, and functions to protect <b7_0>the rest of the flower, especially the bud<b7_0/>. The inner series (corolla of petals) is, <b8_0>in general, white or brightly colored<b8_0/>, and is more delicate in structure. It functions to attract insect or bird pollinators. Attraction is effected by <b9_0>color, scent, and nectar<b9_0/>, which may be secreted in some part of the flower. The characteristics that attract pollinators account for the popularity of flowers and flowering plants among <a4_0>humans<a4_0/>.
